top_categories.workout_context: Crusher in the Tushar’s mixed surface climbing with extended descents and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Crusher in the Tushar’s high-altitude gravel, paved climbs demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Crusher in the Tushar isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Crusher in the Tushar’s mixed surface climbing with extended descents drains energy reserves faster than the distance suggests — durability training bridges the gap.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Crusher in the Tushar when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Crusher in the Tushar rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Every session at Crusher in the Tushar intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Crusher in the Tushar — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Crusher in the Tushar’s 10,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Crusher in the Tushar — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on mixed surface climbing with extended descents.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Crusher in the Tushar. Make this intensity feel like home.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for Crusher in the Tushar’s 10,000ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.

race_overlay.heat: July in Beaver, Utah — July at 10,000+ feet means intense sun, thin air, and afternoon thunderstorms. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Crusher in the Tushar — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Crusher in the Tushar’s 69 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.altitude: Crusher in the Tushar with 10,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Altitude adaptation critical.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Crusher in the Tushar demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride mixed surface climbing with extended descents at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: high-altitude gravel, paved climbs, technical descents. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 69 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 69 miles of mixed surface climbing with extended descents in Beaver, Utah.
